channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report I-2025020062
item.description:
Report I-2025020062

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-05T00:52:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-26
  • City: SANTA FE SPGS
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: QUALITY CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During start of loading operation driver opened storage tank release valve before. connecting hose to CTMV. Material flowed from storage tank into retention area before flow was halted. Hose was connected and shipment was loaded without additional incident. Facility personnel handled released material and processed.properly. Driver received remedial training in proper loading procedures and practices.

item.title: Report I-2025020061
item.description:
Report I-2025020061

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-05T00:52:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-17
  • City: El Segundo
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: QUALITY CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During loading operation driver failed to verify all valves and closures on storage tank, were closed and secured before operation began. As loading started, product was released from the bleeder valve on the storage tank which was not closed. Operations halted and closure sealed on storage tank. Loading completed without additional incident. Facility personnel cleaned released material.

item.title: Report E-2025030019
item.description:
Report E-2025030019

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-04T15:15:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-01
  • City: DES PLAINES
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SET Environmental was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, they observed an estimated (1) gallon of material released from one (1) 330-gallon plastic tote that was cracked at the top of the tote from improper preparation for shipping. SET Environmental personnel observed that the released material impacted 3 ft-by-2 ft of trailer and concrete dock floor. SET Environmental personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and containerized them along with the cut-up tote and PPE into two (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The remaining material in the product tote was to be transferred to two (2) 275-gallon IBC tote. Generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the Dayton Freight Lines team to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report X-2025030003
item.description:
Report X-2025030003

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-04T15:15:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-28
  • City: TONAWANDA
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: John Ognibene, 026 Operation Supervisor, contacted Safety regarding a UN3265 corrosive liquid spill on the trailer and dock floor. John Ognibene advised he noticed the spill while walking the dock. John Ognibene stated it's unknown if any of the commodity struck the yard due to it being dark and the product being clear. John Ognibene advised both sides of the drum are caved in but is unknown if that's what caused the spill. John Ognibene stated the drum is still leaking so he moved the drum off the trailer, down the dock by the dumpster to be out of the way of workers. John Ognibene asked if h e could place wood chips over the spill and Safety advised yes to can contain the spill. Safety contacted Mattisyn Keys with Cura for remediation. ~~Safety advised Mattisyn Keys to advise Safety if any struck the yard and if the spill becomes reportable. Safety also requested the cause of the spill. ~~Update from Cura- "It took some time to get a contractor to respond earlier this morning. The crew just wrapped up at the terminal, completing removal of the environmental concern. The drums looked to have been compressed inside the trailer, causing the release. I am not finding any ingredients o n this product to be reportable."

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Norfolk Southern reported and odor coming from tank car ETCX29060. Upon inspection by a contractor the cause of the leak was excessive Thread Tape on the closure plug that did not allow for secondary closure to be secured. There was a small amount of product found between the primary and secondary closure, possibly from loading operations.

item.title: Report E-2025020417
item.description:
Report E-2025020417

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-04T15:15:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-27
  • City: FREDERICKSBURG
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A 5 gallon container of sodium hydroxide solution was punctured by an exposed nail in a pallet. The Veolia employee identified that the container was leaking and it was removed from the truck immediately. The spill was cleaned from the trailer floor and the dock floor. It is estimated that 3 ounces of material were spilled. The 5 gallon container and spill cleanup were overpacked into a 30 gallon drum without further incident. The pallet was cut into pieces sent for disposal as well.

item.title: Report E-2025020413
item.description:
Report E-2025020413

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-04T15:15:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-26
  • City: DORAL
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: E-2025020413 AT THE UPS AIR CARGO MIAMI FACILITY A SHIPPER PREBUILT UNIT (PBU) AAD99364UPS DESTINED FOR COLOMBIA UNDERWENT CONTENT SCREENING PROCESS. AMONG THE PACKAGES WAS A BLACK SHRINK WRAPPED SKID THAT WAS INSPECTED. ONE FIBERBOARD BOX WITH AN AREA SHAPED AS A DIAMOND CUT FROM THE BOX WAS DISCOVERED. INSPECTION OF THE PACKAGE CONTENTS REVEALED ONE ROINSIDE UP8 PRO SMART E-SCOOTER WITH AN INSTALLED RECHARGEABLE LITHIUM-ION BATTERY. E-2025020415 AT THE UPS AIR CARGO MIAMI FACILITY A SHIPPER PREBUILT UNIT (PBU) AAD1445UPS DESTINED FOR COLOMBIA UNDERWENT CONTENT SCREENING PROCESS. IN BETWEEN THE BOXES INSIDE THE AIR CONTAINER WAS A SODASTREAM TERRA BONUS PACK BOX WITH A PREPRINTED NONFLAMMABLE GAS DIAMOND LABEL. INNER PACKAGE INSPECTION DOES FIND A SODASTREAM COMPRESSED CYLINDERS INSIDE. DANGEROUS GOODS ARE NOT ALLOWED IN SHIPPER PRE-BUILT UNITS.

X-2025021210 During sort operations at the INDH location a fork lift struck a wooden skid and damaged a fiberboard box. The fiberboard box contained two metal cans and spilled all of its contents.   • Description: Upon arrival at the destination terminal, the drum was discovered to be leaking inside the trailer sitting on a skid. The drum was immediately turned up side down and placed into an overpack for containment. Investigation revealed that this drum was punctured by a protruding nail from the skid. The released material was neutralized and containerized for later disposal. The package specifications were not able to be safely obtained.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 18, 2025, one (1) 275-gallon tote of sodium hydroxide had a damaged valve and released approximately ten (10) ounces of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel investigated the tote to ensure it was secure and moved it into a secondary containment area to watch and ensure it would not leak further. Crews secured the scene and demobilized.

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-15
  • City: BERWYN

  • Description: Package was found to be leaking. There is a strong odor of gasoline. DG admin was called and it was discussed the inner contents looked to be brown and in class bottles and there was a very strong odor on gasoline. The package was then held. The customer has called and insist they need their "water" the DG agent let them know that we do not think this is water and that we are turing this over to the FAA for investigation. From our experience we truely believe this is a sample of some sort that contains a high level of gasoline because of the look and the smell of the spill this is not water. Also if it was water you could have shipped it in plastic contianers.

item.title: Report X-2025021182
item.description:
Report X-2025021182

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-04T15:15:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-31
  • City: GEISMAR
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 20000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 02/01/2025 a CN transportation employee observed liquid dripping down the sides of tank car CBTX 726095 while performing switching operations at the CN Geismar Yard in Geismar, LA. The employee notified the on duty transportation manager who then made notification to the CN Dangerous Goods Team. An emergency response contractor was dispatched to the incident for mitigation. The contractor#s assessment noted dried spillage on both sides of the tank car upon arrival. The spillage appeared to be emanating from the manway cover which had an intact security cable seal applied. Further inspection revealed that (2) of the (8) manway cover swing bolts were found to be less than tool tight and could easily be turned by hand. The remaining (6) swing bolts could easily be turned with a pipe wrench with minimal force therefore not creating a proper seal which allowed the contents to leak out during transportation. The manway cover gasket was also inspected and appeared to be in a usable condition. The manway cover swing bolts were tightened in a star pattern with a 24" pipe wrench.

item.title: Report X-2025021177
item.description:
Report X-2025021177

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-04T15:15:09+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-30
  • City: HATTIESBURG
  • State: MS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 15000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: X-2025021177-On 01/30/2025 a CN transportation employee observed liquid coming from the top and running down the side of tank car # TILX 198075 (Loaded / Alcohols N.O.S. / UN 1987 / Class 3) at the CN Hattiesburg Yard located in Hattiesburg, MS. The employee notified the on-duty transportation manager who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team that responded to the incident. The responding DG Officer noted dried spillage on the sides of all 4 of the tank car upon arrival. Further assessment the manway cover swing bolts were less than tool-tight and could easily be turned by hand allowing the contents to leak during transportation due to an improper seal of the manway covers. Shipper-applied security seals were found to be intact at the time of assessment. The manway cover was opened for the purpose of inspecting the gasket followed by the tightening of the swing bolts in a star pattern with a 24# pipe wrench. The tank car was released for continued transportation to destination. There was no ground contamination, exposures or injuries as a result of the leak. X-2025021181-On 01/30/2025 a CN transportation employee observed liquid coming from the top and running down the side of tank car # TILX 193079 (Loaded / Alcohols N.O.S. / UN 1987 / Class 3) at the CN Hattiesburg Yard located in Hattiesburg, MS. The employee notified the on-duty transportation manager who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team that responded to the incident. The responding DG Officer noted dried spillage on the sides of all 4 of the tank car upon arrival. Further assessment the manway cover swing bolts were less than tool-tight and could easily be turned by hand allowing the contents to leak during transportation due to an improper seal of the manway covers. Shipper-applied security seals were found to be intact at the time of assessment. The manway cover was opened for the purpose of inspecting the gasket followed by the tightening of the swing bolts in a star pattern with a 24# pipe wrench. The tank car was released for continued transportation to destination. There was no ground contamination, exposures or injuries as a result of the leak.

  • Description: D&H Petroleum & Environmental Services was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted the asphalt parking lot and estimated that three (3) gallons of material was released due to a improper securement for shipment that resulted in three (3) 5-gallon plastic buckets to fall during offloading. D&H Petroleum & Environnmental Services personnel deployed granular absorbents to impacted area. The spent absorbents were recovered and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was transported offsite for disposal.

  • Description: On February 26, 2025, one (1) 275-gallon tote of UN3264 was damaged in transit and released approximately four (4) tablespoons of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the site. The crew transferred the product to one (1) new 275-gallon tote for continued shipment. The crew utilized absorbent pads to clean the released product. All waste was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and the damaged tote was staged onsite as waste as well/

item.title: Report X-2025021184
item.description:
Report X-2025021184

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-01T21:20:14+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-30
  • City: HATTIESBURG
  • State: MS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Illinois Central Railroad Company
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 15000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 01/30/2025 a CN transportation employee observed liquid coming from the top and running down the side of tank car # TILX 191769 (Loaded / Alcohols N.O.S. / UN 1987 / Class 3) at the CN Hattiesburg Yard located in Hattiesburg, MS. The employee notified the on-duty transportation manager who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team that responded to the incident. The responding DG Officer noted dried spillage on the sides of all 4 of the tank car upon arrival. Further assessment the manway cover swing bolts were less than tool-tight and could easily be turned by hand allowing the contents to leak during transportation due to an improper seal of the manway covers. Shipper-applied security seals were found to be intact at the time of assessment. The manway cover was opened for the purpose of inspecting the gasket followed by the tightening of the swing bolts in a star pattern with a 24# pipe wrench. The tank car was released for continued transportation to destination. There was no ground contamination, exposures or injuries as a result of the leak.

item.title: Report E-2025020406
item.description:
Report E-2025020406

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-01T21:20:14+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-21
  • City: PORT CHESTER
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: SUTTLES TRUCK LEASING, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On January 21, 2025, at 1242 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) were contacted by Suttles Truck Leasing LLC, personnel in Port Chester, NY regarding the release of approximately (1) quart of Unisol Liquid Red BK-50, (Flammable liquid, n.o.s., (Kerosene (Petroleum), Xylenes), UN1993, 3, III) from a hose. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival contractors were informed facility personnel had already performed all cleanup operations, and will manage the waste.

item.title: Report I-2025020068
item.description:
Report I-2025020068

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-01T21:20:14+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-13
  • City: Portland
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PVS TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 11201
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Order was placed for material for 1900 gallons. Tank was a 1550-gallon tank, drivers are instructed to fill tanks to 7/8 to allow room for them to blow out their lines. The driver arrived onsite and hooked up to the tank without any incident. o l. On most occasions the entire load of material should fit into the tank and near the end of the load is when you tend to have issues where the tank gets full. Driver filled tank and initially reported that there was a 5-15 gallon spill out of the top of the tank when he was blowing out his line. •. On 01/22/25 when we received the paperwork and telemetry on the tank it was calculated the actual amount of the spill was 642 gallons. This is above the RQ of 1 0001bs. This was reported to NCR# 1422616 on 01/22/25. A clean-up crew (TAZ Environmental) was contracted to clean the containment area. PVS learned that Ferric Chloride had been pumped into frac tanks from containment and needed to be cleaned out and contracted a new remediation company Miller Septic was contracted. Clean-up of the Ferric Chloride material has been completed.

  • Description: On February 26, 2025, one (1) 275-gallon tote of UN3265 was punctured in transit and released approximately ten (10) gallons to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Mid-South Environmental Services (MSES) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents and neutralizers to remediate the areas. The crew conducted a tote transfer to one (1) new 270-gallon tote. All waste was containerized in three (3) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025020400
item.description:
Report E-2025020400

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-28T00:58:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-21
  • City: BEVERLY
  • State: MA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Veolia employees discovered a leaking 5-gallon carboy when they arrived at the customer location. The 5-gallon carboy was loaded at the previous pick up. Upon locating the leaking container, the employees discovered a screw was lodged in the carboy. The screw appeared to come from a loose panel in the back of the truck. A Veolia employee cleaned up the spill and notified Veolia EH&S. The hole was in the side of the jerrican facing the wall of the truck. A loose board had two screws sticking out of it. One the the screws punctured the jerrican and caused a leak. Duration of the release was about 15 minutes. A little less than half the contents leaked out of the jerrican. Employees overpacked the jerrican into another container and cleaned up the liquid that spilled inside the truck.

item.description:
Report E-2025020366

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-28T00:58:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-14
  • City: BLAKESBURG
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: W2 LOGISTIC INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 50000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On February 14, 2025, a W2 Logistic, Inc tractor trailer was involved in a motor vehicle incident that resulted in a cargo release. The trailer was hauling various drums and totes of non-hazardous, non-regulated, and hazardous UN1760, Corrosive liquids. Approximately 300-500-gallons of various products released to the environment. Local authorities, Mike Lamb from Emergency Management & Homeland Security, and Deran’s Towing Service were on site. Transportation Spill Solutions (TSS) reviewed the report from the Fire Department. According to the report, Mike Lamb and the Fire Department’s Hazmat Team conducted the initial cleanup of the release. The FD indicated that there (3) 55-gallon drums, (3) 250-gallon totes, and (2) 5-gallon buckets near the nose of the trailer. Only (2) 250-gallon totes and (1) 55-gallon drum was leaking inside the trailer. There were (4) 55-gallon drums and (1) 250-gallon tote outside the trailer. FD transferred material into (1) 55-gallon drum, (2) 95-gallon drums, (2) 65-gallon drums, and (1) 35-gallon drum. There was also a hydraulic oil release that was cleaned. All drums were labelled and staged on the side of the roadway.

  • Description: A passenger dropped their cell phone between the seat and the panel. The passenger attempted to retrieve it by moving the seat back and forth. Smoke began to appear from the area, and an FA saw flames. They extinguished it with Halon. Smoke spread throughout the cabin, and passengers remained calm. The FAs had difficulty retrieving the phone because it melted onto the track of the seat. The Captain retrieved the phone using the thermal gloves. Upon safely landing at SFO, the cell phone was retrieved by the San Francisco Fire Department and subsequently handed over to our Maintenance team for inspection. The device was then turned over to the Customer Service Supervisor.

It was reported that approximately 8-10 gallons of synergex released from an IBC Tote due to possibly tipping over ( xpo is waiting on more photos). The release impacted inside trailer#.463-2568. No storm drains or waterways are reported to be impacted by the release. ERTS will proceed to dispatch a contractor to the site to complete cleanup activities. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 20-gallons of UN3149 Synergex product released to an 8’x25’ trailer floor and gravel area underneath trailer which was covered with snow and ice. the tote. Contractors transferred the UN3149 Synergex to a new tote and placed original labels on, rinsed down trailer and containerized (8) 55-gallon poly totes with the neutralized impacted soil, ice gravel, PPE, cardboard and pallet pieces. item.title: Report E-2025020376
item.description:
Report E-2025020376

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-28T00:58:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-27
  • City: VERDIGRIS
  • State: OK
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ACTION RESOURCES, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 55000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver was in route to destination with a loaded truck and tanker; Driver allowed the truck to slowly drift to the right which caused the right side truck tire to go off of the pavement onto a soft shoulder; when driver attempted to steer the truck back onto the road, the tanker right side tires ran off of pavement into the soft shoulder and ditch; this resulted in the truck and tanker rolling over onto its right side. The rollover resulted in a diesel spill from the truck of an estimated 25 gallons and also a very minor drip of product from the load at the air inlet. The fire department responded, and an emergency response crew was dispatched to the scene for product transload into another tanker and the corresponding clean up and restoration. The product was successfully transloaded into another tanker and product was delivered to destination. The environmental cleanup and restoration of the soil have been completed.

item.title: Report I-2025010004
item.description:
Report I-2025010004

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-28T00:58:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-12-05
  • City: WHIPPANY
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: MORRISTOWN& ERIE RAILWAY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: After successfully trans loading product from rail tank car to a truck a minor leak developed at the product line valve flange fitting. To repair this the air was vented from the car and all valves and hoses. The product line hose(two hoses joined together) had been blown out prior to disconnection from the truck and only a small residue of product remained in the hose. The hose was capped off at the truck connection. The leak was repaired and all bolts were re-tighten. To test for leaks at the repair, the employee got off the car and disconnected the two product line hoses so that a pressure cap could be applied on the hose directly attached to the car so this hose would hold air pressure. The first hose off the tank car was hanging in mid air where the connection was made to the second hose. The second hose then came to rest on the loading dock that is adjacent to the tank car. The employee was holding the second hose as he was disconnecting it. As he disconnected it the hose on the dock partially slipped off the loading dock causing the residue product to be run down the hose via gravity(forming a U) and back flow up to the open connection point. The residue material(estimated to be less than a quart) came out and sprayed up and under the employees face shield and onto his face and into his eye. The employee was wearing a complete suit of protective clothing, a hard hat with complete face shield and glasses. The employee immediately got into a wash down shower which was located approximately 15 feet from the incident. Protocols were followed for wash down and for the flushing of the eye as per the emergency response guidelines. The employee removed all his clothing and changed into new clothing. As a precaution he was taken by a coworker to the hospital emergency room to be checked out. He was discharged several hours later after being examined. There was no failure on the part of the equipment or package. The cause was the second hose sliding off the loading dock and gravity forcing the material out of the hose.

  • Description: On February 25, 2025, three (3) 5-gallon pails of paint were damaged and released approximately ten (10) gallons of paint to the trailer interior and dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the site. The crew utilized absorbents, cleaning agents, and hand tools to remediate the surfaces. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and the damaged pails were placed in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: At 0824 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal XAY. It was reported that approximately 2 cups of Unisol Liquid Red BK-50 released from tote due to shipper not properly securing cap. The release impacted trailer #3115335. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel are not capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on site. (Safety Googles) Per the SCM Noah Kelley terminal personnel will perform the cleanup, The terminal used a 10-gallon metal drum to containerize the waste.

All waste was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and the damaged drum of product was overpacked in one (1) 95-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025020273
item.description:
Report E-2025020273

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-26T06:20:57+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-20
  • City: SULPHUR SPRINGS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 20, 2025, at 1817 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar Inway personnel in Sulphur Springs, TX regarding the release of Dynasylan® SILBOND® 40. Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 35.0 gallons of Dynasylan® SILBOND® 40 (UN1993, 3, III) from (1) 55-gallon metal drum onto the trailer floor and asphalt. The release was reportedly due to a load shift, impacting (4) wooden pallets on the trailer floor and a 3’ x 3’ area of asphalt. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. Contractors found that the release was evaporated by the time they arrived on site. With the proper PPE, contractors removed the (1) leaking drum and placed it into an overpack, then removed (5) damaged drums from the pallets to be reviewed by the client for disposition. Impacted pallets and plastic were broken up and containerized. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (3) 55-gallon DFs and (1) 85-gallon poly overpack which were taken onsite by contractors for proper disposal.

item.title: Report X-2025021105
item.description:
Report X-2025021105

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-26T06:20:57+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-19
  • City: ADDISON
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AUDITOR NOTICED FLAMMABLE LIQUID HAZMAT LEAKING IN A LINE FORM FROM TOP CORNER TO BOTTOM CORNER. AUDITOR NOTIFIED SUPERVISOR AND SUPERVISOR NOTIFED RMP TO SEND A RESPONDER TO THE AUDITOR FLOOR AREA. RESPONDER ARRIVED WITH PPE ON, STOCKED SPILL CART, AND CURRENT DECISION TREE. RESPONDER READ AND FOLLOWED CURRENT DECISION TREE, WHICH LED THEM TO THE FLAMMABLE LIQUID RESPONSE SHEET SINCE HAZMAT HAD A FLAMMABLE LIQUID LABEL ON IT. RESPONDER READ FLAMMABLE LIQUID RESPONSE SHEET AND USED ZEP ZORBENT TO CONTAINERIZE THE FLAMMABLE LQUID HAZMAT INTO A SPILL TUB. RESPONDER CLEANED UP REMAINS OF ZEP ZROBENT AND HEADED BACK TO THE PSC CAGE. RESPONDER STARTED PROCESSING AFTER ARRIVING TO THE PSC CAGE.

RESPONDER READ AND FOLLOWED CURRENT DECISION TREE, WHICH LED THEM TO THE FLAMMABLE LIQUID RESPONSE SHEET BASED ON THE FLAMMABLE LIQUID LABEL ON THE PACKAGE. RESPONDER READ CURRENT FLAMMABLE LIQUID RESPONSE SHEET AND USED ZEP ZORBENT TO CONTAIN THE FLAMMABLE LIQUID HAZMAT INTO A SPILL TUB. RESPONDER USED ZEP ZORBENT ON REMAINING SPILL RESIDUE ON THE GRATING AND THE FLOOR. RESPONDER THEN RETURNED TO THE PSC CAGE WITH THE FLAMMABLE LIQUID HAZMAT PACKAGE CONTAINED IN A SPILL TUB. RESPONDER THEN STARTED PROCESSING.

  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately ten (10) gallons of material released from an unknow number of 5-gallon metal pails due to improperly loaded freight that resulted in the pails leaking. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and gathered the spent material and containerized it into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2025020326
item.description:
Report E-2025020326

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-26T06:20:57+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-06
  • City: FREMONT
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On February 6, 2025, an incident occurred during a routine loading operation by a Veolia employee. While transferring containers onto a truck, the worker utilized a drum dolly to transport a 55-gallon polyethylene drum. Upon setting the drum down inside the vehicle, the employee observed approximately one pint of clear liquid pooling around the drum's base. Further inspection revealed a small hole at the bottom of the drum, which was the source of the leak. To contain and manage the spill, the worker promptly employed vermiculite and absorbent pads. These materials effectively prevented the liquid from spreading and facilitated the cleanup process. To ensure safe transportation to the intended facility, the compromised drum was placed inside an overpack container. This additional precaution allowed for the secure continuation of the drum's journey to its final destination.

  • City: NORTON

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: @ totes/IBCs, as described, loaded aboard van type trailer from pickup at Alnylam (Cambridge, MA) and enroute to Elizabeth, NJ. During loading stop at Alnylam (Norton, MA) driver conducted periodic check of load and discovered small liquid release on top of IBCs. Note, spillage remained on top of IBCs due to small qty of liquid leaked and product was cleaned up by our in-hours staff. New gaskets were used to replace existing gaskets that were on tank. Closures then tightened down to precise torque specifications from package manufacturer. Load continued to it's ultimate destination.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-04
  • City: VINELAND
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 08:08 ET, XPO notified the Call Center of a cargo release at terminal XVL. It was reported that approximately 2 ounces of Total Solutions Vanquish released from one box containing four 1-gallon poly jugs due to improper loading by previous terminal. The release impacted only the carboard box container of the four 1-gallon jugs, the spill occurred on trailer #3212702 and was discovered on Dock #08 after being unloaded. Service Center Manager Michael Martucci gave permission for terminal personnel to clean up the spill. Waste label 226598-1 was created, one 5-gallon poly drum containing the carboard box containing four 1-gallon poly jugs. INFOTRAC was notified report #382116 was provided by Bobby.

item.title: Report E-2025020005
item.description:
Report E-2025020005

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-26T06:20:57+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-29
  • City: Waycross
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 1/29/25, at 11:31 hours, personnel in the CSXT Rice Yard in Waycross, Georgia, discovered UTLX 663268, a residue tank car which last contained Environmentally Hazardous Substances, Liquid, NOS, leaking from bottom of the tank car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Shell Chemical, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2025012900116). Hulls Environmental, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found product leaking from the bottom outlet valve of the tank car. Contractor personnel identified that the bottom outlet valve was in the open position and bottom outlet valve’s secondary closure cap was less than tool tight. Response personnel closed the valve and properly secured the secondary closure cap. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Jeffery Bowes).

item.title: Report E-2025020004
item.description:
Report E-2025020004

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-26T06:20:57+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-26
  • City: Tampa
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 1/26/25, at 16:58 hours, personnel in the CSXT McCloskey Yard, in Tampa, Florida, discovered PVCX 13298, a loaded tank car of Sulfuric Acid leaking from top of tank car. The car was isolated and the shipper, Nyrstar Corporation, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2025-0126-00018). Hulls Environmental, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found product leaking from top of the tank car. Contractor personnel found that the liquid line primary closure cap to be less than tool tight; and that the closure cap gasket was deteriorated. Response personnel applied a 2” pipe cap to the NPT threaded unloading adapter portion of the liquid line closure assembly to stop the release. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Bradley Turner). The car was held at location pending further repair by a certified tank car repair shop or One Time Movement Approval.

  • Description: At 0947 ET, XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal XML. It was reported that approximately 1 quart of UN1866 released from 1) 55-gallon metal drum due to improper loading. The release impacted trailer # 3178627. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and determined that terminal personnel are capable of cleaning the release with PPE available on site. The terminal does not currently have any drums onsite. Terminal will update waste container once drum received. The impacted drum is not impeding dock operations. XPO advised an overpack will be ordered and utilized once received. The current damaged drum is not actively leaking.
